Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: High - Reliability and Low - Cost Design of Electric Motor for Automotive Industry Application
Award.AbstractNarration:
The recent need for clean energy and the decreasing availability of fossil fuels have resulted in a noticeable progress in research and application of power generation based on alternative energy sources. Electric Motors and Generators are important components in the green technology, generating or consuming majority of the electric energy from alternative energy sources, especially in public transportation area including automotive industry and aerospace industry. As the rare-earth-material-based three-phase electric machine has been popularly applied to the public transportation systems (for power management, energy storage, etc.) where safety is a priority, cost and reliability have also become critical market issues. This I-Corps team's focus is, therefore, on the design of high-reliability, low-cost electric machines that are fault-tolerant and free of rare-earth materials to meet the needs of target market segmentation in automotive industry.

The target product will be a Rare-earth material Free Multiphase Synchronous reluctance Motor (FMSM). Unlike the conventional low-power machine, which is designed as a single- or three-phase machine, the proposed multiphase motor is designed using a 5-phase architecture, an optimal solution to provide the lowest cost and highest reliability among all theoretically and practically available low-power machines in the market. The proposed architecture also provides compact size and extended lifetime with reduced electro-magnetic interferences (EMI). To further reduce manufacturing costs, Rare-earth materials will be substituted by Ferrite materials. Ferrite materials are abundant in nature and about 10 times cheaper than Rare-earth materials. In addition, the output power will be generated based on an innovative and alternative torque generation mechanism which will lead to further reduced costs in material utilization while significantly simplifying the design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our target product of this NSF I-Corps Team project is a high reliability and low cost design of electric motor for automotive industry application. As part of this project, we (PI, two entrepreneur student leaders, and one external business mentor) have further investigated the target market of our team's design. For this, our team has performed more than 100 extensive face to face interviews with potential customers. Eventually, we identified that the high reliability characteristic of our motor design can significantly reduce down time while ensuring safety and avoiding costly failure in application to mining truck, military gun turret, and electric bicycle.

Intellectual merit: Unlike the conventional electric motors which are mostly designed with three phase or single phase, the proposed machine has multiphase architecture. This multiphase machine design has been re-created with rare-earth free material which provides lowest cost and highest reliability among practically available electric motors in the market. However, the rare-earth free material commonly shows low efficiency, higher torque ripple, and low power density, and higher demagnetization possibility in the machine design. With unique and optimal design of magnetic flux barrier, we have identified that we can successfully overcome such a drawback. To verify this, we have successfully designed four prototypes which details have been published in multiple  academic journals and acamdemic conference presentations.  

Broader impact: This project will have significant impact on the new design and control of high energy efficiency, high power density, and high reliablity of electric machine in ranges of applications in transportation electricfication including hybrid/electric vehicle and more electric aircraft propulsion system. This project has provided training opportunities for two entrepreneur students (one undergraduate student in mechanical engineering and one graduate student in electrical engineering) to educate them as future leaders and entrepreneurs in the automotive industry.

Modified by: Seungdeog Choi
